form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Ms. Baldwin (for herself, Mr. King, Mr. Wyden, and Mr. Peters) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation

form.official-title: To require the Secretary of Commerce to undertake certain activities to support waterfront community revitalization and resiliency.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Waterfront Community Revitalization and Resiliency Act of 2015.

paragraph.text: many communities in the United States were developed along waterfronts;
water proximity and access is a recognized economic driver;
water shortages faced by parts of the United States underscore the need to manage water sustainably and restore water quality;
interest in waterfront revitalization and development has grown, while the circumstances driving waterfront development have changed;

waterfront communities face challenges to revitalizing and leveraging water resources, such as outdated development patterns, deteriorated water infrastructure, industrial contamination of soil and sediment, and lack of public access to the waterfront, which are often compounded by overarching economic distress in the community;
public investment in waterfront community development and infrastructure should reflect changing ecosystem conditions and extreme weather projections to ensure strategic, resilient investments;
individual communities have unique priorities, concerns, and opportunities related to waterfront restoration and community revitalization; and
the Secretary of Commerce has unique expertise in Great Lakes and ocean coastal resiliency and economic development.
The term resilient waterfront community means a unit of local government or Indian tribe that is—

clause.text: bordered or traversed by a riverfront or an inland lake;

subparagraph.text: self-nominated as a resilient waterfront community; and

designated by the Secretary as a resilient waterfront community on the basis of the development by the community of an eligible resilient waterfront community plan, with eligibility determined by the Secretary after considering the requirements of subsections (b) and (c) of section 4.

paragraph.text: The term Secretary means the Secretary of Commerce.
Subject to paragraph (2), the Secretary shall designate resilient waterfront communities based on the extent to which a community meets the criteria described in subsection (b).

For inland lake and riverfront communities, in making the designation described in paragraph (1) and promulgating criteria and best practices, the Secretary shall work with the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency and the heads of other Federal agencies, as the Secretary determines to be necessary to provide comparable services to waterfront communities not located on Great Lakes or ocean coasts.

subsection.text: A resilient waterfront community plan is a community-driven vision and plan that is developed—

paragraph.text: voluntarily at the discretion of the community—

subparagraph.text: to respond to local needs; or
to take advantage of new water-oriented opportunities;

paragraph.text: with the leadership of the relevant governmental entity or Indian tribe with the active participation of—

subparagraph.text: community residents;
utilities; and
interested business and nongovernmental stakeholders;

paragraph.text: as a new document or by amending or compiling community planning documents, as necessary, at the discretion of the Secretary;
in consideration of with all applicable State and Federal coastal zone management planning requirements;
to address economic competitive strengths; and
to complement and incorporate the objectives and recommendations of applicable regional economic plans.

subsection.header: Components of a resilient waterfront community plan
subsection.text: A resilient waterfront community plan shall—

paragraph.text: consider all, or a portion of, the waterfront area and adjacent land and water to which the waterfront is connected ecologically, economically, or through local governmental or tribal boundaries; and
describe a vision and plan for the community to develop as a vital and resilient waterfront community, integrating consideration of—

subparagraph.text: the economic opportunities resulting from water proximity and access, including—
the community relationship to the water, including—

clause.text: public access, particularly in areas in which publicly funded ecosystem restoration is underway;

subparagraph.text: ecosystem challenges and projections, including unresolved and emerging impacts to the health and safety of the waterfront and projections for extreme weather and water conditions;
infrastructure needs and opportunities, to facilitate strategic and sustainable capital investments in—

clause.text: protection against storm surges, waves, and flooding;
stormwater, sanitary sewer, and drinking water systems, including green infrastructure and opportunities to control nonpoint source runoff; and
other community facilities and private development; and

subparagraph.text: such other factors as are determined by the Secretary to align with metrics or indicators for resiliency, considering environmental and economic changes.

subsection.text: After the designation of a community as a resilient waterfront community under subsection (a), a resilient waterfront community plan developed in accordance with subsections (b) and (c) shall be—

paragraph.text: effective for the 10-year period beginning on the date on which the Secretary approves the resilient waterfront community plan; and
updated by the resilient waterfront community and submitted to the Secretary for the approval of the Secretary before the expiration of the 10-year period.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall develop a resilient waterfront communities network to facilitate the sharing of best practices and technical assistance among waterfront communities.

In consultation with designated resilient waterfront communities, the Secretary shall provide formal public recognition of the designated resilient waterfront communities to promote tourism, investment, or other benefits.

The Secretary shall establish within the Department of Commerce a program under which the Secretary shall provide planning and implementation grants that leverage other sources of public and private investment to assist with the following eligible activities:

paragraph.text: The development of resilient waterfront community plans, including such costs as planning and feasibility analysis.
Implementation of strategic components of a resilient waterfront community plan, once a plan has been approved by the Secretary.
A unit of local government or an Indian tribe shall be eligible to apply as a lead applicant for a grant under subsection (a) if the unit of local government or Indian tribe is—

subparagraph.text: bound in part by—
bordered or traversed by a riverfront or an inland lake.

paragraph.text: Subject to subsection (d)(3), a lead applicant may provide a subaward to an eligible subawardee for implementation activities described in subsection (d)(2).
Planning funds received through a grant under subsection (a) shall be used to develop a resilient waterfront community plan.
In developing a resilient waterfront community plan using amounts made available under subsection (a), a resilient waterfront community may—

subparagraph.text: conduct community visioning and outreach;
identify challenges and opportunities;
develop strategies and solutions;
prepare plan materials, including text, maps, design, and preliminary engineering;
collaborate across local agencies and work with regional, State, and Federal agencies to identify, understand, and develop responses to changing ecosystem and economic circumstances; and

conduct other planning activities that the Secretary considers necessary for the development of a resilient waterfront community plan that responds to revitalization and resiliency issues confronted by the resilient waterfront community.

paragraph.text: Implementation funds received through a grant under subsection (a)—

subparagraph.text: shall be used to initiate implementation of a resilient waterfront community plan and facilitate high-quality development, including leveraging local and private sector investment; and
may be used on 1 or more eligible activities to address strategic community priorities that are identified in the resilient waterfront community plan.

paragraph.text: Grant funds may be used flexibly across 1 or more eligible implementation costs, such as—

subparagraph.text: site preparation;
environmental review;
engineering and design;
acquiring easements or land for uses such as green infrastructure, public amenities, or assembling development sites;
updates to zoning codes;
construction of—

clause.text: public waterfront or boating amenities; and

subparagraph.text: infrastructure upgrades to improve coastal resiliency;
economic and community development marketing and outreach; and
other activities at the discretion of the Secretary.
To assist in implementing eligible implementation activities, a lead applicant may grant subawards from implementation funds to eligible subawardees, including—

The lead applicant shall ensure that grant funds, including funds awarded as a subaward, are used for the purposes of, and in a manner consistent with, the waterfront community revitalization grant program.

subsection.header: Specifications on use of grant funds

paragraph.text: A grant made under this section shall be not less than $50,000 or more than $1,000,000.

In accordance with the grant agreement, a resilient waterfront community shall spend no more than $200,000 of any grant awarded under this section on planning activities, with remaining grant award balances reserved for implementation activities after the approval of the Secretary of an approved resilient waterfront community plan.

subparagraph.text: A resilient waterfront community receiving a grant under this section shall provide non-Federal matching funds toward completion of an eligible project in an amount equal to not less than 25 percent of the grant amount.
Non-Federal matching funds may be provided by—

clause.text: 1 or more units of local or tribal government;

subparagraph.text: The Secretary shall treat as non-Federal matching funds the value of in-kind contributions of land or easements held in perpetuity by the resilient waterfront community.

paragraph.text: In establishing obligation and expenditure periods for grants under this section, the Secretary shall provide grant periods that enable funds to be used strategically to match private or public sector investments in planning and implementation.

subsection.text: At regular intervals, the Secretary shall provide a list of resilient waterfront communities to the applicable States and the heads of national and regional offices of interested Federal agencies, including at a minimum—

paragraph.text: the Secretary of Transportation;
the Secretary of Agriculture;
the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency;
the Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency;
the Assistant Secretary of the Army for Civil Works;
the Secretary of the Interior; and
the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.

subsection.text: To encourage consideration of opportunities for synergistic projects and timelines, the Secretary shall coordinate awareness of designated resilient waterfront communities among managers of relevant Federal grant and loan programs that fund projects or infrastructure that are addressed in a resilient waterfront community plan.

section.header: Preferential grant status for Federal funding

subsection.header: Department of Commerce grant and loan programs
subsection.text: The Secretary shall provide to designated resilient waterfront communities preferential status in select grant and loan programs of the Department of Commerce, including—

paragraph.text: the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration;
the Economic Development Administration; and
other relevant entities under the authority of the Secretary.

subsection.text: Considering the integration in resilient waterfront community plans of myriad components and project types traditionally funded through separate agencies and departments and the opportunity that resilient waterfront communities present for resilient long-term investment, the heads of other interested Federal agencies and departments, including the agency heads described in section 7(a), are encouraged to provide designated resilient waterfront communities with preferential status in grant and loan programs.

section.text: There is authorized to be appropriated to the Secretary to carry out this Act $50,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2016 through 2020, to remain available until expended.
